1468257397382815752.text: Doris Miller should have received the Medal of Honor. He put his life on the line for a country that treated him like a second-class citizen. We can, and we must correct this injustice by awarding him the Medal of Honor posthumously.

1468257270249181191.text: In January of 2020, the Secretary of the Navy announced the naming of a future aircraft carrier in his honor—the U.S.S Doris Miller (CVN-81). It is the first aircraft carrier named for an enlisted sailor and African American. This was a massive step forward, but it is not enough. https://t.co/kbc2Q6GHUT

1468257140112568326.text: Two years later, Doris Miller was aboard on the U.S.S. Liscome Bay when it was struck by a torpedo off the coast of Butaritari Island in the Western Pacific. He and over 600 other sailors onboard the ship were presumed dead and their bodies were never recovered.

1468257026891526144.text: But when the time came for official recognition, Miller, who was listed as an “unnamed Negro,” received only a letter of commendation while 15 of his shipmates received the Medal of Honor. It wasn’t until the NAACP requested proper recognition that he was awarded the Navy Cross. https://t.co/G9WgS9GkXG

1468256905546145792.text: Per the U.S.S. West Virginia’s action report, Miller was “instrumental in hauling people along through oil and water to the quarterdeck, thereby unquestionably saving the lives of a number of people who might otherwise have been lost.”

1468256796267716610.text: When the attack began, he immediately left his post in the laundry room to rescue shipmates injured in the initial barrage and to defend the harbor. He is credited for manning an anti-aircraft gun, for which he had no training, and providing cover fire until ordered off the ship. https://t.co/PAbwaHjJ30

1468256674838372354.text: Doris Miller was born in Waco, Texas in 1919. After high school, he enlisted in the Navy as a mess attendant—one of the few positions available for Black sailors. He was assigned to the U.S.S. West Virginia, which was stationed at Pearl Harbor the morning of December 7th, 1941.

1468256542894043147.text:
Today marks the 80th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor. More than 2,400 lives were lost, and our nation was forever changed.

Many heroes were made on that fateful day, but let me tell you the story of one you may not have heard of before—Doris Miller. https://t.co/Ft02FATh1v

Thank you to @ACBiH, .@EliKula, and Munira Subasic for a successful #BosnianWomensDay 

#Genocide #Prevention https://t.co/RTXMfz9Ve1

723219104673361920.text: #BosnianWomensDay has come to an end.  It was a powerful reminder of the importance of #Genocide #Prevention

723216291721547776.text: .@EliKula: "A lot of the youth want to leave #Bosnia. Brain drain is a problem." #BosnianWomensDay

723216128307171328.text: .@EliKula: "Children in #Bosnia are willing to listen, but not yet to totally accept the truth about the #bosniawar

723214587433086976.text: .@EliKula: "#Syria should involve more women in the reconciliation process than Bosnia did." #BosnianWomensDay

723214415739281408.text: Advice for the aftermath of the war in #Syria from Murina: "Do not divide the country into enclaves after the war." #BosnianWomensDay

723213519139696640.text: .@EliKuna: "Ask our politicians to agree to deals that include long-term goals, and we must work with locals." #BosnianWomensDay

723212975868276736.text: .@EliKuna: "Politicians will always use nationalist rhetoric when trying to get elected, but education is key for reconciliation."

723212726676258818.text: .@EliKuna: "Our children are learning three different versions of history, and that focus in education in #bosnia is what we need most."

723212557335465986.text: .@EliKuna: "I do not think that we yet have embarked on reconciliation...what we do need is education."

723212403874263042.text: Murina: "No one in Bosnia is working on trust." #BosnianWomensDay

723211804525101058.text: Answer from Murina: "Not as long as politicians and public figures keep making public statements denying what happened."

723210935658123265.text: Q1: "Given the amount of #GenocideDenial in Bosnia and Herzegovina, what will it take to have reconciliation?" #BosnianWomensDay

723209854291075075.text: I remember the conversation I had with @EliKula that created #BosnianWomensDay, and with it, a space to talk about #genocide #prevention

723209508063875074.text: .@EliKula: "We have a serious problem processing war crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina." #BosnianWomensDay

723209316900052992.text: .@EliKula: "We cannot expect victims of the #genocide to be the first people to reach out for the reconciliation process."

723209124771590145.text: .@EliKula: "As long as we hold on to the past and teach people about it, we can embrace it and move forward."

723208518694768640.text: Mu Di is a refugee who sits on the Dallas Youth Commission to advise Dallas’ City Council on her experience #WWWP https://t.co/eE81RLTEBc

723208188942639104.text: Munira: "Every victim deserves to be properly buried." #BosnianWomensDay

723207921501261825.text: Munira: "I would like to thank the American government for its role in the search parties." #BosnianWomensDay

723207454264152064.text: Munira: "We do not have a law prohibiting the denial of genocide, and the world should help us create one."
